name: Enabling Access for the Deaf: Different Perspectives
description:
Join us for a panel discussion that delves into the critical role of interpreting services in fostering accessible and inclusive organisational environments. 

Through this event, you can learn about the challenges ISL interpreters face, discover best practices for effective communication, and discuss potential solutions to enhance accessibility for Deaf individuals. The session aims to foster understanding, collaboration, and a shared commitment to creating inclusive workplaces for all.

name: Make at MAP: Collagraphy Printmaking
description:
Join us for Make at MAP and create your own unique print! This edition is inspired by the exhibition Rhyme Unbroken - Krishna Reddy as Artist and Perpetual Student. Explore the versatile technique of collagraph printmaking, where a printing plate is created using a collage of materials, offering endless possibilities for texture and design. Learn how to assemble a collagraph plate and create stunning prints that reflect the unique style of Krishna Reddy's work. 

Make at MAP is a series that allows you to explore our collection in an engaging and hands-on manner. These sessions allow you to create and take home a special souvenir of your visit.

It is perfect for all ages — so bring your friends and family and get ready to make some art! No experience is necessary, just a willingness to have fun and experiment with new materials.

Workshop timings: 

11:30-1:00

2:00- 3:30

name: Films Screenings + Discussion by The Third Eye Learning Lab
description:
Join us for the screening of three shorts Raat: Night Time in Small Town India, Khushi's Roshni and Kya Hai Yeh Samjhauta? Co-created and worked on in The Third Eye's Learning Lab through varied processes, this screening will be followed by a discussion with The Third Eye Learning Lab team and Hansa Thapliyal.

About the films:

Raat (35 min):A documentary exploring the hidden lives and experiences of people in small-town India during the night.

Khushi’s Roshni (7 min): A short film featuring Khushi Bano exploring the complexities of online identity and self-representation among young Muslim women in India.

Kyaa hai ye Samjhauta?(Dur. 9 min): A short film exploring women's experiences with domestic violence, and the choices they make in response to it.

Note: All the films will be in Hindi with English subtitles.

Credits

Raat:

Mentor: Ruchika Negi, Editor: Abhinava Bhattacharyya, Sound (post production): Abhishek Mathur, Assistance: Madhuri Adwani, Producer (for The Learning Lab): Dipta Bhog, Ruchika Negi, Producer (for The Third Eye): Shabani Hassanwalia, Shivam Rastogi

Khushi's Roshni:

Mentor: Ruchika Negi, Editor: Gurleen Grewal, Producer: The Third Eye’s Learning Lab

Kyaa hai ye Samjhauta?:

Direction - Hansa Thapliyal, Camera - Nebu George and Pankaj Baral, Sound Design -  Amir Musanna, Sound Final Mix - Shashank Kothari, Art Direction - Koshy Brahmatmaj, Edit - Hansa Thapliyal, Producer: The Third Eye

workPresented.name: Films Screenings + Discussion by The Third Eye Learning Lab

name: Trivia Night Extravaganza
description:
Get ready for a night of fun, laughter, and learning at our inclusive trivia event. Test your general knowledge and Indian Sign Language (ISL) skills in a lively quiz that's accessible to everyone, regardless of hearing ability.

Join us as we celebrate International Week of Deaf People and raise awareness about Deaf culture. This event is a great opportunity to have fun, make new friends, and support a cause that matters.

Connect with the Deaf community, learn about their experiences, and advocate for inclusivity. Together, let's create a more inclusive and accessible world for all.

This event is in collaboration with Soapstone Fellows from Hear A Million and Enable India

Note: This ticket grants free admission to the event. To enjoy food, please purchase a separate food coupon here

name: Reframing the Visual Depiction of Women and Sexual Violence in Southasia
description:
Fear, intimidation, objectification and victims are the predominant themes in images used to depict sexual violence against women in the media. Can you visualise images that are more empowering, more nuanced, that show women in all their complexity, that show resilience and resistance? Be a part of challenging and changing this visual discourse

Come, share your talent, share your vision in this workshop facilitated by the Hri Institute for Southasian Research in conjunction to their project Challenging Visual Depiction of Women and Sexual Violence in Southasia which aims to challenge gender insensitive visual and aural depiction of sexual violence against women in Southasia. 

Thanks to robust women’s movements in the region, the rising incidents and brutality of incidents of sexual violence has been met with strong protests and demands for accountability. Considerable strides forward have been made to improve media reporting of sexual violence, making it less sensational, more based on women’s lived experiences, gender-sensitive and ethical. However, images that accompany news-reports tend to remain stereotypical and even damaging by reinforcing stigma, helplessness, shame and victim-blaming. Join this workshop and learn to create a more empowering and compassionate visual narrative.

Selected works (sketches, paintings, cartoons, photos) will be showcased on the website of the Hri Institute as part of the pool of stock images that exists.

name: Rise and Sign: Breaking Taboos Together
description:
It’s time to speak up! Join us for a panel discussion focused on addressing social taboos. The panel will feature both Deaf and hearing individuals working at the intersection of various themes such as gender, LGBTQ+ and disability.

This discussion will explore different perspectives on how we can collectively address and overcome societal taboos. It seeks to inspire attendees to reflect on their own role in confronting these issues,and advocate for positive change in their communities.

name: Sketching workshop: Painting with Fire (12:00PM)
description:
There is art hidden everywhere, and when you view it with an artist's vision, it suddenly becomes evident, as if it had been in plain sight all along. Discover the stories that can be found within a piece of wood by closely examining artworks at our latest exhibition Painting with Fire, and join us for a sketching workshop led by Penciljam.

Painting with Fire, features the art of Jeram Patel and Tarik Currimbhoy, who both use fire on wood to present the unique possibilities  concealed within pieces of wood.

This method of creating art can be seen in light of what may stem from the material or process. Some sculptors, for instance, describe their process as chipping away at marble to reveal the sculpture hidden inside or game artists who build characters starting from random squiggles of ink.

In this session, we will explore this unique human ability to create meaningful forms and interpretations out of seemingly random shapes. We will discover how artistic vision utilises both chance and skill to create art.


What you need to Bring along

- A sketchbook
- A Black Gel Pen / Micron / Pigment Liner
- A Black Brush Pen (Optional)

If you would like to register for our 4:00PM session click here.

description:
There is art hidden everywhere, and when you view it with an artist's vision, it suddenly becomes evident, as if it had been in plain sight all along. If you would like to register for our 12:00PM session click here.

name: The Childbirth Experience: Advocating for Respect and Dignity
description:
How can a sense of agency, care and respect influence the experience of childbirth? This panel discussion explores the importance of respect and dignity in maternal healthcare, focusing on the experiences of women during pregnancy and childbirth in India. 

The artwork Mother and Child 2 by Nilima Sheikh offers a powerful visual representation of the maternal experience. It depicts a mother and her newborn, appearing as if they were drawn with a single, continuous line. The larger series that this painting is a part of, captures moments of the mother holding, nursing, and steadying her child – telling of the deep bond between them. However, the subtle hints of wounds and tears on the mother's body in this painting remind us of the physical and emotional challenges women face during childbirth.

Join us for a discussion that delves into the current state of maternal care, addressing the challenges that women face in healthcare settings and the stigma that surrounds their experiences in the maternal healthcare landscape. This discussion will cover public and private sectors but with a special focus on public sector hospitals.

Our panellists, Dr Janhavi Nilekani, Mandira Kalra Kalaan, and Jamuna L, will be in conversation with Anoushaka Chandrashekar. They will also address the role of advocacy, awareness, and outreach in transforming maternity care practices.

This event is conceptualised under our exhibition VISIBLE/INVISIBLE: Representation of Women in Art through the MAP Collection.

name: Beyond the Gender Beat
description:
A report by The Media Rumble and UN Women in early 2019 analysed India’s leading newspapers, magazines, TV channels, and news websites. It found that in a six-month period in 2018, only 8% of content—news reports, features, opinion pieces, and primetime debates—focused on gender issues.

This is alarmingly low. A sustained focus on understanding the issues, interests and concerns of women and gender minorities is crucial to undoing the patriarchal systems that bind us.  Non-sexist representation that moves beyond outrage cycles and victim shaming is key to reshaping narratives. This requires both a shift in content and the structure of journalistic institutions to address gender issues beyond sensationalism. Sensitive storytelling should centre the voices of women and gender minorities, critically explore widening gender disparities, and adopt new, compassionate ways to present these stories.

Join us for a panel discussion featuring Priti David from PARI (People’s Archive of Rural India), Laxmi Murthy from Hri Southasian, Priyanka Tupe from Behan Box, and Shabani Hassanwalia from The Third Eye. Each of these institutions, in their distinct ways, have employed a people-first approach in storytelling; allowing to build sensitivity and instances for continued learning around gender.

This panel discussion is conceptualised under our exhibition VISIBLE/INVISIBLE: Representation of Women in Art through the MAP Collection.

name: A People-First Approach in Reporting by PARI
description:
Join us for a workshop by the People’s Archive of Rural India (PARI) that will explore a people-first approach in reporting with a special focus on gender. Designed for early-career professionals, aspiring journalists, and communications practitioners, the session will guide writers on how to craft compelling stories about the lives and livelihoods of everyday Indians.

 Conducted by Vishaka George, Senior Editor at PARI, this session will cover finding overlooked stories, obtaining consent, interviewing, photography tips, and crafting compelling narratives, with hands-on exercises to sharpen skills.
